description: When you are first start programming, solving problems can be difficult. Since the entire impetus for learning programming is to solve a multitude of problems with a computer, the difficulties can lead to frustration. However, in this course, we are going to approach a problem with a method that can help alleviate those issues. Join us as we develop our problem-solving toolkit!

name: Algorithmic Problem Solving
subtitle: Problem Solving Step by Step

episodes.description: When you are first start programming, solving problems can be difficult. Since the entire impetus for learning programming is to solve a multitude of problems with a computer, the difficulties can lead to frustration. However, in this course, we are going to approach a problem with a method that can help alleviate those issues. Join us as we develop our problem-solving toolkit!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.939
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.939 --> 00:00:06.731
>> Hello and thank you for
watching DevProTV,

3
00:00:06.731 --> 00:00:09.697
we're talking to Justin Dennison
about algorithmic problem solving.

4
00:00:09.697 --> 00:00:12.540
So Justin, tell us about the course.

5
00:00:12.540 --> 00:00:17.160
>> The course is meant to allow
to us think about how to plan.

6
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:18.522
How to kind of grock,

7
00:00:18.522 --> 00:00:23.610
which is a terminology that means just
fully understand a respective problem.

8
00:00:23.610 --> 00:00:27.246
And in this course, what we're gonna do
is we're gonna take an approach of, well,

9
00:00:27.246 --> 00:00:28.730
how do I approach a problem?

10
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:31.163
How do I algorithmically
approach something?

11
00:00:31.163 --> 00:00:35.730
And that's up for debate.

12
00:00:35.730 --> 00:00:39.568
This is a little bit of a biased
opinion here, so in this course.

13
00:00:39.568 --> 00:00:44.392
But with them, we'll have a series of
projects where we have planning phase and

14
00:00:44.392 --> 00:00:45.400
a coding phase.

15
00:00:45.400 --> 00:00:48.142
So the planing will be let me draw,
what do I know?

16
00:00:48.142 --> 00:00:50.268
How do these things work?

17
00:00:50.268 --> 00:00:51.943
Let's see if I can break it and

18
00:00:51.943 --> 00:00:55.766
it's more about understanding
what's called the problem space.

19
00:00:55.766 --> 00:00:59.410
Instead of just going well,
let me write some code here.

20
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:04.298
So the entire goal is to solve actual
problems though, they are small in

21
00:01:04.298 --> 00:01:09.105
nature by applying a process that
should be applicable over a larger,

22
00:01:09.105 --> 00:01:11.151
more complex problem space.

23
00:01:11.151 --> 00:01:13.520
>> And Justin,
who is this show targeted towards?

24
00:01:13.520 --> 00:01:15.890
>> This is someone who's maybe just
getting started with programming,

25
00:01:15.890 --> 00:01:17.384
maybe wants to know
a little bit more about.

26
00:01:17.384 --> 00:01:19.344
Maybe they programmed before, but

27
00:01:19.344 --> 00:01:24.490
they're like I'm having trouble figuring
out what I'm supposed to do next.

28
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:31.166
This show is to help those individuals
say, I need to do thing X.

29
00:01:31.166 --> 00:01:33.680
How do I accomplish thing X?

30
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:37.388
Well, I need to follow these
kind of steps in order to okay,

31
00:01:37.388 --> 00:01:39.919
that's how I put all of these together.

32
00:01:39.919 --> 00:01:43.570
So the goal is to help people
who are having trouble.

33
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:45.264
Maybe they know a little bit,
maybe they don't.

34
00:01:45.264 --> 00:01:50.254
How do I actually accomplish things that
I have original ideas for that maybe I

35
00:01:50.254 --> 00:01:55.830
don't know where to get started or how
to progress in some reproducible manner.

36
00:01:55.830 --> 00:01:57.897
>> Is there a certification available for
the course?

37
00:01:57.897 --> 00:01:59.900
>> This is not a certification course.

38
00:01:59.900 --> 00:02:03.325
This is kind of one of those heady
topics where we're gonna do a little

39
00:02:03.325 --> 00:02:04.221
bit of thinking.

40
00:02:04.221 --> 00:02:06.393
And by a little bit, I mean, a lot and

41
00:02:06.393 --> 00:02:09.350
then we're gonna make sure
we have some drawing.

42
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:13.148
I'm gonna try to show you my
thought process, which maybe you

43
00:02:13.148 --> 00:02:17.910
might have to tweak for yourself and
then we're going to do the application.

44
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:22.580
As a result, it would be very hard
to certify something like this.

45
00:02:22.580 --> 00:02:25.057
You're a certified
algorithm problem solver.

46
00:02:25.057 --> 00:02:29.780
So this is more about getting better
in order to move forward in your craft.

47
00:02:29.780 --> 00:02:32.503
>> And you've already kind of test on it,
but what topics are covered in this show?

48
00:02:32.503 --> 00:02:36.304
>> So that the topics are mostly
in an abstract sense planning and

49
00:02:36.304 --> 00:02:38.801
then actually implementing or coding.

50
00:02:38.801 --> 00:02:41.952
But along that, we're gonna be
building a Caesar sign for it.

51
00:02:41.952 --> 00:02:44.806
We're gonna be making a title function.

52
00:02:44.806 --> 00:02:49.063
We're gonna look at how to wait for it or
wait for it, figure out palindromes.

53
00:02:49.063 --> 00:02:51.620
There's a couple of other problems and

54
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:56.281
these are small that I've picked,
because they should be short to do.

55
00:02:56.281 --> 00:02:59.388
But they can have some issues
that are nice to highlight.

56
00:02:59.388 --> 00:03:04.238
And well, there's a couple other things
where we're going to hijack the Python

57
00:03:04.238 --> 00:03:07.030
system to give us some
quick iteration times.

58
00:03:07.030 --> 00:03:08.131
So I try something.

59
00:03:08.131 --> 00:03:08.810
It's broke.

60
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:10.735
It's not broke.
So being able to do that,

61
00:03:10.735 --> 00:03:15.110
that fast feedback is imperative to know,
am I on the right track?

62
00:03:15.110 --> 00:03:17.171
Or am I totally off base?

63
00:03:17.171 --> 00:03:18.600
>> Well, thank you, Justin.

64
00:03:18.600 --> 00:03:21.295
And if algorithmic problem
solving sounds like a course,

65
00:03:21.295 --> 00:03:23.391
you would be interested in and
you should be.

66
00:03:23.391 --> 00:03:27.700
Make sure to get all the episodes and
see them in our course library.

67
00:03:27.700 --> 00:03:28.689
Thanks you very much for watching.

68
00:03:28.689 --> 00:03:31.181
And remember,
a good DevPro is always learning.

69
00:03:31.181 --> 00:03:36.291
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore how to approach solving a problem algorithmically.
episodes.title: Approaching a Problem
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.186 --> 00:00:16.272
Hello everyone, and welcome back
to another edition of DevproTV.

3
00:00:16.272 --> 00:00:17.865
I'm your host Vonne Smith and

4
00:00:17.865 --> 00:00:21.515
we're starting our series on
algorithmic problem solving.

5
00:00:21.515 --> 00:00:24.330
In this episode we're going
to be approaching a problem.

6
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:28.191
And here to solve all of our
problems in all of our lives is Mr.

7
00:00:28.191 --> 00:00:30.628
Justin Dennison, how are you today?

8
00:00:30.628 --> 00:00:31.609
[LAUGH]
>> I am doing well,

9
00:00:31.609 --> 00:00:36.270
I am now absolutely terrified that you
have over-promised what I'm gonna deliver

10
00:00:36.270 --> 00:00:38.145
on, but I'm doing fairly well.

11
00:00:38.145 --> 00:00:40.145
How are you Vonne?
>> I'm doing pretty good.

12
00:00:40.145 --> 00:00:44.746
I'm curious to see where we are going to,
sorry I'm approaching a problem.

13
00:00:44.746 --> 00:00:49.320
I feel like I probably do this
all the wrong ways of my life.

14
00:00:49.320 --> 00:00:52.781
So I'm hoping maybe I can get some
life lessons out of this, maybe or

15
00:00:52.781 --> 00:00:55.711
we're just going with coding,
what're we doing here?

16
00:00:55.711 --> 00:00:59.505
>> So for this episode we're actually
gonna stay away from programming in this

17
00:00:59.505 --> 00:01:00.640
particular episode.

18
00:01:00.640 --> 00:01:03.923
It's about how do I think, how do I
tumble around all the things that I

19
00:01:03.923 --> 00:01:06.490
need to consider when I'm
trying to solve a problem?

20
00:01:06.490 --> 00:01:09.685
Now, this is not limited
just to your programming,

21
00:01:09.685 --> 00:01:11.727
I actually use this a great deal.

22
00:01:11.727 --> 00:01:15.310
Sometimes I'm out in my little workshop
trying to build something, right.

23
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:18.011
Build something out of wood I know,
it's crazy,

24
00:01:18.011 --> 00:01:20.533
I'm more of a primitive
individual in there.

25
00:01:20.533 --> 00:01:25.076
But I'm like, wait,
this is what I have, wait I need,

26
00:01:25.076 --> 00:01:29.840
what are my goals, so
I apply a very systematic approach.

27
00:01:29.840 --> 00:01:33.348
Now, before we go there,
algorithmic, right.

28
00:01:33.348 --> 00:01:38.179
I just said systematic approach,
algorithmic, what, that's kinda odd,

29
00:01:38.179 --> 00:01:39.070
right?

30
00:01:39.070 --> 00:01:41.128
What does that mean?
Well an algorithm,

31
00:01:41.128 --> 00:01:45.393
I'm going to oversimplify here,
just bear with me.

32
00:01:45.393 --> 00:01:49.416
It is a set of steps that can
be reproducibly accomplished,

33
00:01:49.416 --> 00:01:54.515
store done in order to arrive at
that particular destination, right.

34
00:01:54.515 --> 00:01:59.113
So if I start at point A and I know how to
get to point B through these reproducible

35
00:01:59.113 --> 00:02:02.961
steps, if I always start at point
A I should always get to point B.

36
00:02:02.961 --> 00:02:08.080
Okay, now, we all know that life
is not always that clean cut.

37
00:02:08.080 --> 00:02:10.798
So do bear with me,
this is a recommendation,

38
00:02:10.798 --> 00:02:13.796
a formalized system to help
you try to think about,

39
00:02:13.796 --> 00:02:18.820
okay, I've developed something that will
always get me from Point A to Point B.

40
00:02:18.820 --> 00:02:23.152
Assuming that there's not a pothole
between Point A and Point B, so

41
00:02:23.152 --> 00:02:24.529
do keep that in mind.

42
00:02:24.529 --> 00:02:30.650
Now a lot of you are like well this
seems very math sciencey kinda oriented.

43
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:35.246
Well, I'm gonna try my best to
draw on some previous experiences

44
00:02:35.246 --> 00:02:38.853
where we're not necessarily
talking about that.

45
00:02:38.853 --> 00:02:44.045
But you kinda do this already, maybe
not in a systematic way, but I'm gonna

46
00:02:44.045 --> 00:02:49.580
hopefully provide a framework that will
allow you to do this more reproducably?

47
00:02:49.580 --> 00:02:53.471
>> And this is, of course,
in the context of how you code.

48
00:02:53.471 --> 00:02:58.128
And so this is probably something that
you do any time that you're like, okay,

49
00:02:58.128 --> 00:02:59.670
I need to create this app.

50
00:02:59.670 --> 00:03:02.711
Or even something really small,
like I need to create this block of code.

51
00:03:02.711 --> 00:03:04.574
You still go through this same,

52
00:03:04.574 --> 00:03:08.783
kinda like a checklist before you
approach any of your coding problems.

53
00:03:08.783 --> 00:03:10.950
And like you said your wood working and
everything.

54
00:03:10.950 --> 00:03:13.640
>> You're exactly correct,
I think of it as a checklist.

55
00:03:13.640 --> 00:03:18.590
And full disclosure this came
about mainly because I was

56
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:22.179
more of a science math oriented person.

57
00:03:22.179 --> 00:03:25.560
Actually, I had a very kinda of
artistic bent in me when I was younger.

58
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:29.180
I've kind of left that behind,
sadly just because of life.

59
00:03:29.180 --> 00:03:33.647
But, I started creating this checklist
step one, I'm going to do this,

60
00:03:33.647 --> 00:03:37.810
step two I'm going to do this,
step three I'm going to do this.

61
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:43.479
And by applying those steps I was able
to see where am I, where am I going.

62
00:03:43.479 --> 00:03:46.254
And do I need to take any details so
to speak,

63
00:03:46.254 --> 00:03:49.970
in order to figure out,how
do actually get there?

64
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:52.705
>> I'm also going to assume, since you've
maybe been doing this for a while,

65
00:03:52.705 --> 00:03:54.211
I know you've been teaching for a while.

66
00:03:54.211 --> 00:03:56.729
Do you get questions from your students?

67
00:03:56.729 --> 00:03:59.320
I know I would be like,
I don't even know where to start.

68
00:03:59.320 --> 00:04:03.208
I don't even know what to do, and
you just throw your hands up and

69
00:04:03.208 --> 00:04:04.580
it's too difficult.

70
00:04:04.580 --> 00:04:08.480
>> That's actually why I
started doing this myself.

71
00:04:08.480 --> 00:04:11.952
Because essentially when people
say I don't know where to start,

72
00:04:11.952 --> 00:04:15.862
as an instructor, as a teacher,
I go what do you know, I don't know?

73
00:04:15.862 --> 00:04:19.880
You know nothing, you're telling me
you know, you don't know anything?

74
00:04:21.192 --> 00:04:22.058
I do know something.

75
00:04:22.058 --> 00:04:27.024
If you helped figure out where you
are in the first process, then I'm more,

76
00:04:27.024 --> 00:04:29.204
I can more effectively help you.

77
00:04:29.204 --> 00:04:31.830
Likewise, if you know where
you are in the process,

78
00:04:31.830 --> 00:04:35.666
you know what kind of questions to ask,
where to go find the answers to them.

79
00:04:35.666 --> 00:04:42.020
So this is helpful, with that said not
everybody does it even after I fail them.

80
00:04:42.020 --> 00:04:46.528
>> And I've done the same answer
when my teacher, I just don't know.

81
00:04:46.528 --> 00:04:50.853
Cuz you're already at that frustration
Frustration level that you kinda

82
00:04:50.853 --> 00:04:51.904
just break down.

83
00:04:51.904 --> 00:04:55.493
And your wall's brought up, and
you're just like, I don't know anything.

84
00:04:55.493 --> 00:04:57.651
And then you're like,
wait, no, just calm down.

85
00:04:57.651 --> 00:05:02.388
So that way, maybe before you get to that
frustration level, hat we're saying,

86
00:05:02.388 --> 00:05:07.004
just kind of stop and think about this
algorithmic problem solving checklist.

87
00:05:07.004 --> 00:05:10.277
And hopefully, you might not
get yourself tube twisted and

88
00:05:10.277 --> 00:05:12.381
crying in a corner like I normally do.

89
00:05:12.381 --> 00:05:17.441
>> Well, actually this should help
because this is something you should

90
00:05:17.441 --> 00:05:22.670
be able to do with relative ease maybe
you stuck some part alone the way but

91
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:25.150
it allows you to go, I know this.

92
00:05:25.150 --> 00:05:28.500
This is what I've done,
I have a small victory.

93
00:05:28.500 --> 00:05:31.160
But now where do I go from here, right?

94
00:05:31.160 --> 00:05:34.642
I've kind of jumped across the stones and
now I'm in the middle of the river going,

95
00:05:34.642 --> 00:05:37.674
I don't know which stone to jump on next,
but that's okay because I know

96
00:05:37.674 --> 00:05:41.130
you're in the middle of the river, or you
know you're in the middle of the river.

97
00:05:41.130 --> 00:05:44.609
You're like, okay,
well I've kind of gotten this far,

98
00:05:44.609 --> 00:05:49.793
what's my next little step?Now, we've
talked in very strong generalities there.

99
00:05:49.793 --> 00:05:54.767
This is personally, in my opinion,
this is not backed up by

100
00:05:54.767 --> 00:05:59.351
empirical research, but
this has been very helpful.

101
00:05:59.351 --> 00:06:03.288
I've seen it been helpful to
a great deal of other people, so

102
00:06:03.288 --> 00:06:05.386
this is anecdotally backed up.

103
00:06:05.386 --> 00:06:08.290
That is a hard word to say, anecdotally.

104
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:11.100
>> I'm glad you tried that and
not me, [LAUGH] I'm like keep going.

105
00:06:11.100 --> 00:06:13.235
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm just going to sit here and go.

106
00:06:13.235 --> 00:06:14.932
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So let's go ahead and

107
00:06:14.932 --> 00:06:15.882
take a look at the iPad.

108
00:06:15.882 --> 00:06:19.002
We're gonna do a little bit of drawing,
which interestingly enough,

109
00:06:19.002 --> 00:06:20.490
how do I solve a problem?

110
00:06:20.490 --> 00:06:24.277
I recommend you always
start with draw a picture.

111
00:06:24.277 --> 00:06:27.270
Now, what do I mean by draw a picture?

112
00:06:27.270 --> 00:06:32.154
That could be as simple as making a list
if you're doing something numeric like

113
00:06:32.154 --> 00:06:36.530
list all the numbers, draw a diagram,
they don't have to be pretty.

114
00:06:36.530 --> 00:06:41.104
As a matter of fact, if you spend a lot of
time going I'm gonna draw this exactly to

115
00:06:41.104 --> 00:06:44.420
scale with,
you're probably avoiding the other parts.

116
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:48.074
So draw picture, draw a diagram,
and when I say draw,

117
00:06:48.074 --> 00:06:53.090
just start writing more or less to try
to wrap your mind around the concept.

118
00:06:53.090 --> 00:06:56.030
>> Well it's like they say
back to the drawing board.

119
00:06:56.030 --> 00:06:59.588
Plan it out, I know as instructors
it's almost in our nature,

120
00:06:59.588 --> 00:07:03.079
as soon as we start talking about
something, we wanna go up and

121
00:07:03.079 --> 00:07:06.120
get a pen on the board, and
just start writing it out.

122
00:07:06.120 --> 00:07:10.768
Because that way I can kind of just
visualize it a little bit more if I just

123
00:07:10.768 --> 00:07:11.940
put pen to paper.

124
00:07:11.940 --> 00:07:17.114
Or electronic pen to iPad just to
kinda get it down in that format,

125
00:07:17.114 --> 00:07:21.268
rather than kinda just thinking of it,
put it down.

126
00:07:21.268 --> 00:07:25.280
>> You're exactly correct, and to some
extent this is not a high pressure thing.

127
00:07:26.470 --> 00:07:30.156
Just put pencil to paper or
marker to whiteboard or

128
00:07:30.156 --> 00:07:32.977
pencil to iPad, this isn't an iPen.

129
00:07:32.977 --> 00:07:35.995
But don't actually write on your iPad.

130
00:07:35.995 --> 00:07:39.623
It's more of a free thinking thing
to see if your mental model,

131
00:07:39.623 --> 00:07:44.157
what you've kind of thought about in
your head, meshes with the other parts.

132
00:07:44.157 --> 00:07:46.450
Now what are the other parts?

133
00:07:46.450 --> 00:07:48.627
Well, list what you know, all right?

134
00:07:48.627 --> 00:07:51.350
Now, there's are like facts.

135
00:07:51.350 --> 00:07:54.978
So if you're in a construction site, well,

136
00:07:54.978 --> 00:08:00.424
I know have 34 two-by-fours,
right, or 60 pounds of nails.

137
00:08:00.424 --> 00:08:06.017
I know I need 90 pounds of nails,
and 124 two-by-fours,

138
00:08:06.017 --> 00:08:11.620
well, you kinda already started
molding where you're going.

139
00:08:11.620 --> 00:08:14.154
Now, you're asking,
where's the picture of that?

140
00:08:14.154 --> 00:08:18.190
Well the picture is probably already given
to you, kind of a diagrammed picture.

141
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:21.679
So list what you know,
and these are facts.

142
00:08:22.710 --> 00:08:26.925
You forgot the word know, list what you-
>> What you know.

143
00:08:26.925 --> 00:08:27.868
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

144
00:08:27.868 --> 00:08:31.811
that actually shouldn't
be list what you know.

145
00:08:31.811 --> 00:08:35.989
Okay, so there's a list what you know.

146
00:08:35.989 --> 00:08:37.520
There we go, writing is hard.

once you really broke it down,

374
00:22:40.350 --> 00:22:44.298
like when you're like, I'm like, yeah.

375

You said a lot of people
don't even consider that.

376
00:22:48.040 --> 00:22:53.180
Because I'm just going over here,
you're like no, stop, look at the problem.

377
00:22:53.180 --> 00:22:57.270
Draw it out, I mean that was
just really a cool example of

378

what you need to just kinda stop,
it's really more of like stop and

smell the roses, or stop and

380
00:23:06.689 --> 00:23:11.929
[LAUGH] And get to that particular answer,
and the other thing that I've

kinda come away from this is we don't
film everything in all of the orders.

382
00:23:17.560 --> 00:23:22.565
I've been through a couple of your
episodes and shows where you do this and

you always start off all of your coding
problems or that particular episode.

384
00:23:27.828 --> 00:23:29.850
Okay, so this isn't in the part

385
00:23:29.850 --> 00:23:31.080
Now what what do we know?

386
00:23:31.080 --> 00:23:32.130
Where do we need to go?

387
00:23:32.130 --> 00:23:34.445
And I'm like, I see it.

388
00:23:34.445 --> 00:23:35.440
[LAUGH].

389
00:23:35.440 --> 00:23:39.040
So this has been pretty cool for
me to watch you do this.

390
00:23:39.040 --> 00:23:43.366
[LAUGH] Well, hopefully it sticks with
you and here as excited as Vonne but

391
00:23:43.366 --> 00:23:44.840
this is a quick recap.

392
00:23:44.840 --> 00:23:45.390
What do we do?

393
00:23:45.390 --> 00:23:46.810
We draw our picture, right?

394
00:23:46.810 --> 00:23:48.690
I mean I always draw a picture but

395

sometimes that picture
can be in your mind.

396
00:23:50.330 --> 00:23:55.920
I do recommend when in doubt,

00:23:55.920 --> 00:23:56.590
It doesn't have to be beautiful.

398
00:23:56.590 --> 00:23:59.502
I mean, come on, that was bad.

00:23:59.502 --> 00:24:01.125
I left out units and things, but

400
00:24:01.125 --> 00:24:03.845
it's meant to help you keep
context about your goal.

401
00:24:03.845 --> 00:24:07.967
It's also to help you inform, kind of
inform, what are the things I know?

402
00:24:07.967 --> 00:24:10.774
Cuz I can't tell you how many
times I talked to people and

403
00:24:10.774 --> 00:24:13.176
they're like, I got an eight by ten room.

404
00:24:13.176 --> 00:24:14.302
I'm like, cool.

405
00:24:14.302 --> 00:24:15.314
Well how tall are the ceilings?

406
00:24:15.314 --> 00:24:16.845
Why do you need to know that?

407
00:24:18.755 --> 00:24:22.131
Seems like a, right,
glean as much information.

408
00:24:22.131 --> 00:24:25.565
Now this is very artificial,
kind of contrived.

409
00:24:25.565 --> 00:24:28.887
But by taking some of those relationships,

410
00:24:28.887 --> 00:24:33.841
maybe something you never thought
way back that you'd not need.

411
00:24:33.841 --> 00:24:36.331
And just applying
incremental little pieces.

412
00:24:36.331 --> 00:24:38.852
Trying to reduce as much as you can.

413
00:24:38.852 --> 00:24:40.705
Manipulating things.

414
00:24:40.705 --> 00:24:41.743
So draw a picture.

415
00:24:41.743 --> 00:24:43.075
Write down what you know.

416
00:24:43.075 --> 00:24:47.057
Sometimes what you know,
you keep adding to the what you know part.

417
00:24:47.057 --> 00:24:52.028
You're like yeah, I do know that, yeah, I
do know that, yeah, I do know that, right?

418
00:24:52.028 --> 00:24:54.405
And then what is your goal, right?

419
00:24:54.405 --> 00:24:56.618
What's next, or
what you need to know, right?

420
00:24:56.618 --> 00:24:59.153
What are your needs?

421
00:24:59.153 --> 00:25:01.683
You may find out that's still
a long stretch and then,

422
00:25:01.683 --> 00:25:05.264
that's when you apply the fourth step
where you start reducing the problem.

423
00:25:05.264 --> 00:25:10.224
Changing what you know,
right, by certain rule sets.

424
00:25:10.224 --> 00:25:13.083
All right, I can't just go,
seven, all right.

425
00:25:13.083 --> 00:25:16.328
Don't do things like that and
then reduce the problem.

426
00:25:16.328 --> 00:25:18.615
Or what if I only needed
to paint one wall?

427
00:25:18.615 --> 00:25:20.139
What if I wanted to paint the floor?

428
00:25:20.139 --> 00:25:26.127
What if I, I don't know, wanted to
paint a one square foot tile, right?

429
00:25:26.127 --> 00:25:28.207
Change and see if you can make progress.

430
00:25:28.207 --> 00:25:32.782
It'll keep you less frustrated and it will
help you make progress on a more complex

431
00:25:32.782 --> 00:25:35.851
problem, so
those are my four steps that I recommend.

432
00:25:35.851 --> 00:25:37.100
It is not exhaustive.

433
00:25:37.100 --> 00:25:40.363
It is not researched to the nth-degree.

434
00:25:40.363 --> 00:25:43.253
A lot of people had variations on this,
but

435
00:25:43.253 --> 00:25:48.726
it will help you at least get a formalized
approach of what do I need to do, right?

436
00:25:48.726 --> 00:25:50.844
Where do I get started so to speak.

437
00:25:50.844 --> 00:25:54.956
>> Well, I feel empowered to go
tackle all of my problems and

438
00:25:54.956 --> 00:25:57.278
solve every single one of them.

439
00:25:57.278 --> 00:26:01.880
[LAUGH] But it really does, when you
break it down to that smallest common

440
00:26:01.880 --> 00:26:05.727
denominator, it does make big
problems seem a lot easier.

441
00:26:05.727 --> 00:26:08.136
So anything else to add there, Justin?

442
00:26:08.136 --> 00:26:09.865
>> Well, just keep this in mind,

443
00:26:09.865 --> 00:26:13.861
I'm gonna try to always reemphasize
this even if I'm non-explicit.

444
00:26:13.861 --> 00:26:16.424
Do know, I'm doing this in my head.

445
00:26:16.424 --> 00:26:19.473
It has served me well,
it's not always rainbows and,

446
00:26:19.473 --> 00:26:21.804
sometimes you go well that didn't work.

447
00:26:21.804 --> 00:26:24.461
But that's okay, you know what?

448
00:26:24.461 --> 00:26:27.038
Essentially you added to
the list of things you know and

449
00:26:27.038 --> 00:26:28.669
now you can reattack the problem.

450
00:26:28.669 --> 00:26:30.171
So don't worry.

451
00:26:30.171 --> 00:26:32.302
>> All right, well I'm feeling
better about myself [LAUGH] and

452
00:26:32.302 --> 00:26:34.232
I hope y'all are feeling
better about yourself too.

453
00:26:34.232 --> 00:26:37.149
But we are going to go ahead and
wrap this one up.

454
00:26:37.149 --> 00:26:40.109
So signing off for DevPro.TV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

455
00:26:40.109 --> 00:26:40.857
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

456
00:26:40.857 --> 00:26:42.862
>> And we'll see you soon.

457
00:26:42.862 --> 00:26:46.407
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the problem of finding the maximum number in a list of numbers...

0 very similar, right?

People go, it's always the last one.

The assumption if you did that,

00:05:41.017 --> 00:05:45.788
You can't make that assumption, because

that's not the last one that breaks.

00:05:48.768 --> 00:05:53.645
So your ultimate goal in drawing a picture

00:05:53.645 --> 00:05:55.768
And any time you have a supposition,

00:05:55.768 --> 00:05:58.726

Now, this deviates from just

well what if that happened,
what if you threw this one,

what if I had four numbers,
what if I have it in a different order.

118
00:06:17.272 --> 00:06:22.384
And so you can kinda be able
to determine next steps.

119
00:06:22.384 --> 00:06:23.100
>> Well, you're close.

120
00:06:23.100 --> 00:06:23.924
>> Okay.

>> To some extent you're helping

you do this to help build what do I know,

00:06:32.964 --> 00:06:38.559
And to some extent you need to be aware,

125
00:06:38.559 --> 00:06:41.395
We're gonna draw one final picture here.

What if I say -1, -3 and 0

if I look at that, well,

[SOUND] you are like hold on,

00:07:03.752 --> 00:07:06.807

00:07:06.807 --> 00:07:09.481

00:07:09.481 --> 00:07:10.634
I don't wanna be in debt.

00:07:10.634 --> 00:07:14.795
But I'm at zero then that's the maximum

135
00:07:14.795 --> 00:07:20.768
So by thinking about all of these things,

136
00:07:20.768 --> 00:07:24.947
Well so here are my knows,

00:07:29.106 --> 00:07:31.286
The list can be any size.

138
00:07:35.017 --> 00:07:40.317
Right, so I have, I did three just for

00:07:40.317 --> 00:07:45.510
but really there's nothing

140
00:07:45.510 --> 00:07:49.748
I did four up here, so
the list can be any size.

141
00:07:49.748 --> 00:07:53.398
The list can be any order.

142
00:07:58.704 --> 00:08:03.259
All right, now, this is a list of
numbers that's kind of implicit.

143
00:08:03.259 --> 00:08:06.449
So what else do I know?

144
00:08:06.449 --> 00:08:12.236
There is, A maximum.

145
00:08:14.502 --> 00:08:19.819
I know that seems kinda odd to say I know

146
00:08:19.819 --> 00:08:24.000
But as I was making this,
I thought of another what if scenario.

147
00:08:26.498 --> 00:08:32.412
What if I come here and
draw another picture and I go, 1,3,3.

148

00:16:20.131 --> 00:16:22.610
Long term,
you're like I learned some new things.

285
00:16:22.610 --> 00:16:25.100
Which is faster, which is more readable?

286
00:16:25.100 --> 00:16:27.890
If I come here,
there's a lot that I have to do.

287
00:16:27.890 --> 00:16:30.040
This is a little more declarative.

288
00:16:30.040 --> 00:16:34.440
Join together with the empty string
the reversed portion of a string.

289
00:16:34.440 --> 00:16:37.833
It's a little easier to read,
here I go okay,

290
00:16:37.833 --> 00:16:42.540
I have an empty string and
then I run through, what is this mean?

291
00:16:42.540 --> 00:16:45.028
I have to think about that and
then if I come back,

292
00:16:45.028 --> 00:16:48.499
is it perfectly okay to have code
like this, that solves a problem?

293
00:16:48.499 --> 00:16:53.990
But you may come later on and change
it over to something like this, okay?

294
00:16:53.990 --> 00:16:57.774
So there is not always one particular
solution to any given problem and

295
00:16:57.774 --> 00:16:59.837
sometimes it's language specific.

296
00:16:59.837 --> 00:17:01.800
We're using Python so these are available.

297
00:17:03.420 --> 00:17:06.954
If you're joining us in our journey
you will be using Python as well.

298
00:17:06.954 --> 00:17:12.129
But eventually you may adopt a different
language that do not have these utilities

299
00:17:12.129 --> 00:17:17.086
and well, this algorithm is movable to
a variety of different environments.

300
00:17:17.086 --> 00:17:22.250
But technically we have achieved our goal.

301
00:17:22.250 --> 00:17:27.250
One last thing, though,
assert reverse_string

302
00:17:27.250 --> 00:17:31.430
of the empty string should give me the
empty string, I should get nothing back.

303
00:17:31.430 --> 00:17:33.859
You should always, empty to empty, right?
>> Okay.

304
00:17:33.859 --> 00:17:35.290
>> Let's see if it works.

305
00:17:35.290 --> 00:17:39.950
And it in fact does, so
there was another edge case, okay?

306
00:17:39.950 --> 00:17:41.980
Does our original algorithm work?

307
00:17:43.280 --> 00:17:48.490
Well comment that out,
uncomment that, and I run it.

308
00:17:48.490 --> 00:17:52.540
Boom, it still works,
that is a fairly robust solution.

309
00:17:52.540 --> 00:17:58.880
Assuming that these are the outputs that
you expect and just by thinking through,

310
00:17:58.880 --> 00:18:01.250
stating the problem, drawing some
pictures, and then coming here and

311
00:18:01.250 --> 00:18:05.960
codifying it to try to solidify that
thinking, we have a workable algorithm.

312
00:18:05.960 --> 00:18:10.230
Very simple, but as a building block,
this pattern of looping through and

313
00:18:10.230 --> 00:18:13.050
kind of accumulating is very prominent
in a bunch of other problems.

314
00:18:13.050 --> 00:18:15.580
So as you start to see these patterns,

315
00:18:15.580 --> 00:18:20.590
other issues that would crop up normally
start to become a little bit clear and

316
00:18:20.590 --> 00:18:24.420
they just become easier.
>> Awesome stuff, Justin, well done.

317
00:18:24.420 --> 00:18:27.500
Reversing a String Coding,
the title of this episode.

318
00:18:27.500 --> 00:18:30.937
And before we leave you and say bye bye,
and come back another time,

319
00:18:30.937 --> 00:18:35.549
what else would you like to say?
>> Well, one final thing, small steps,

320
00:18:35.549 --> 00:18:40.500
small pieces and always think about,
I have something working.

321
00:18:42.120 --> 00:18:45.630
And then, only then when it works,
when you know that it

322
00:18:45.630 --> 00:18:50.370
does exactly what it's supposed to, then
do you worry about making it better, okay?

323
00:18:50.370 --> 00:18:54.097
As long as you're getting better every
day, incrementally getting better,

324
00:18:54.097 --> 00:18:56.646
then over the long haul
everything'll be all right.

325
00:18:56.646 --> 00:18:58.460
So don't be too hard on yourself.

326
00:18:58.460 --> 00:19:01.820
If you're like, this is kinda ugly, or
this isn't as fast as I would like to,

327
00:19:01.820 --> 00:19:03.317
whatever it may be, get it working.

328
00:19:03.317 --> 00:19:04.600
That's the most important part.

329
00:19:04.600 --> 00:19:09.373
And if you don't believe me,
then think about would you rather not be

330
00:19:09.373 --> 00:19:14.225

to wherever because you have a Ferrari

331
00:19:14.225 --> 00:19:16.850
without an engine.
>> [LAUGH]

332
00:19:16.850 --> 00:19:18.782
>> Or would you rather go hop out into

333
00:19:18.782 --> 00:19:22.232
a Geo Metro that has started on
the first try, every time and

334
00:19:22.232 --> 00:19:24.230
reliably gotten you to work.

335
00:19:24.230 --> 00:19:26.110
Just think about that,
that's all I'm saying.

336
00:19:26.110 --> 00:19:27.304
>> Well said, great advice.

337
00:19:27.304 --> 00:19:30.510
Algorithmic Problem Solving
is a wonderful series.

338
00:19:30.510 --> 00:19:33.640
Make sure you watch every single episode
too because you'll be glad you did.

339
00:19:33.640 --> 00:19:37.040
And you'll be in the course library
where there's thousands of other videos

340
00:19:37.040 --> 00:19:39.190
all designed to help you go further.

341
00:19:39.190 --> 00:19:40.580
So check those out as well.

342
00:19:40.580 --> 00:19:42.576
And tell everybody you
know about DevProTV,

343
00:19:42.576 --> 00:19:44.108

344
00:19:44.108 --> 00:19:46.730
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

345
00:19:46.730 --> 00:19:48.773
>> And we will see you again soon.

346
00:19:48.773 --> 00:19:53.768

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss what a palindrome is as well as explore and develop a plan for determining if a string is a palindrome is or not.
episodes.title: Detect Palindromes: Planning
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

Greetings everyone, and welcome back to

A palindrome, you can think of

T-A-C-O C-A-T.

>> Wait, I had to

that is a long one, and just so

But our goal is to see if we

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So I'm gonna show you the

But in all honesty,

[LAUGH] Vonne was like, I was hoping

And the reason being is what

What if this is all you want to do and

You need to know a little different way,

Also, this is a way of comparing

I've been talking in

Interestingly enough, hm,

How is that,

All right, so now if I go,

Yeah, this goes here,

as soon as you got past like the A,

We're in a little bit of

But are we going to,

Can you say detect all non-breaking

>> Well, Vonne,

157

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We sure can.

But let's go ahead and finish our

keep that thought.

Nothing wrong with that question,

00:08:42.050 --> 00:08:46.952
That's how you should be thinking,

which means that if we follow our same
pattern as soon as we hit a space, for

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach create a function that provides a title case version of a supplied string. Justin further explores how to take a first pass solution and make changes to increase readability.
episodes.title: Creating a Title: Coding

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss what a Caesar Cipher is as well as create a plan, after exploring the problem, necessary for implementing a caesar cipher function.
episodes.title: Caesar Cipher: Planning

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach implement a basic Caesar cipher function that will take a string and a number of character shifts to apply to the incoming string. Justin demonstrates how a first solution may handle all of the edge cases appropriately and how one could fix those issues.
episodes.title: Caesar Cipher: Coding

00:24:58.490 --> 00:25:03.508
